metadata.title: Recent advances in antibacterial applications of metal nanoparticles (MNPs) and metal nanocomposites (MNCs) against multidrug-resistant (MDR) bacteria

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 3 March 2019 Accepted 1 May 2019
KEYWORDS Multidrug resistance; nanomaterials; metal nanoparticles; metal nanocomposites; antibacterial mechanisms

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Emergence of the antibiotic resistance in microorganisms causing infectious diseases has been more problematic for health and economy [1]. Annually, 100,000 tons of antibiotics are produced to treat bacterial infections. However, these antibiotics have failed to control Multidrug-resistant (MDR) bacteria, and therefore, there is a pressing need of a novel antibiotic which can be effective against MDR. Resistance as value of ≥1 antimicrobial agent in three or more antimicrobial groups is referred to as MDR [2]. Based on the information of World Health Organization, antibiotic resistance in infectious diseases including tuberculosis, pneumonia, salmonellosis, gonorrhea, and infected chronic wounds is a major concern. The present review is mainly focused on MDR bacteria causing infected wounds such as diabetic foot ulcers and bacterial infections caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria [3]. Other important MDR bacterium is Streptococcus pneumoniae, which causes bronchitis, meningitis, rhinitis, acute sinusitis, otitis media, osteomyelitis, conjunctivitis, sepsis, septic arthritis, endocarditis, cellulitis, brain abscess, and peritonitis particularly in immunocompromised patients [4]. Development of MDR can be possible by several mechanisms involving chemical modifications and degradation of antibiotic agents, reduction in antibiotic penetration by alteration of porin proteins and application of efflux pumps,modification of target sites via enzymatic and mutational changes as well as acquisition of resistance genes [1]. Recently, nanotechnology has presented novel way to fight against MDR pathogens. The application of metal nanoparticles (MNPs) with a size of less than 100 nm in different shapes was effective because of their unique properties compared to their bulk counterpart. MNPs such as Ag, Cu, Fe3O4, TiO2, and ZnO have shown different antibacterial activities based on physicochemical properties of each metal element [5,6]. Among these, MNPs and AgNPs demonstrated more antibacterial ability by using several mechanisms [7]. In addition to elemental structure, size and shape ofMNPs play key role in this activity. Interestingly, there are several reports pertaining to antibacterial activity of MNPs with smaller size [8]. In this regard, synthesis methods of MNPs can determine antibacterial activity. Generally, there are two methods involving top-down and bottom-up approaches for synthesis of nanoparticles (NPs) which are dependent on use of physical and chemical methods, respectively. Based on the above facts, the present review is focused on (1) types of MNPs synthesis, (2) pathogenicity and MDR mechanisms of MDR bacteria, and (3) antibacterial activity of MNPs against MDR bacteria.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis methods of MNPs
sections.text:
The formation of NPs is described by two steps of nucleation from seeds and growth of nuclei by reduction and coalescence processes, respectively. These steps may occur differently in liquid, solid, and gas phases. In this review, focus has beenmade on liquid

MNPs can be divided in two groups involving MNPs (Ag, Cu, Au, and Pt) and metal oxide NPs (Fe3O4, ZnO, CuO, Cu2O, MgO, and TiO2). There are several methods based on top-down (almost physical) and bottom-up (almost chemical) approaches for synthesis of MNPs (Figure 1). As shown in Table 1, advantages and disadvantages of biosynthesis methods are illustrated. In this case, metal salts (e.g. AgNO3, CuSO4, and HAuCl4) are used for synthesis, reducing agents (NaBH4, sodium citrate, and ascorbic acid), and capping agents (polymers, citrate, and thiol) in chemical reduction methods (Figure 2) [9]. In green synthesis of MNPs, pure biomaterials or extracts related to plants, bacteria, fungi, algae, lichens, yeasts, and viruses are applied as reducing and capping agents [10].
NPs: nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3. Pathogenicity and mechanisms of MDR bacteria
sections.text:
Now it is well known that microorganisms have developed resistance to one or several antibiotics. These abilities are resulted from evolution process. However, other mechanisms with
biochemical and molecular aspects are involved in acquired resistance of MDR bacteria. For a better understanding of these mechanisms, in following sections, mechanisms of MDR by important bacterial pathogens involving Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria are presented. There are various mechanisms concerning antibiotic resistance which includes target protein mutation, antibiotic inactivation by specific enzymes, low susceptibility of target protein by acquisition of related genes, the target bypassing, and application of efflux pump for inhibition of drug access to target. For example, in E. coli mutation in ribosomal protein (RpsL) can cause resistance to streptomycin. Inactivation of target protein is usual resistance mechanism against natural antibiotics such as aminoglycosides. Utilization of β-lactamases, adenylation, acetylation, and phosphorylation is a common way of enzymatic inactivation [1,11]. MRSA strain is resulted from horizontal transformation of penicillin-binding protein 2a (PBP-2a) from non-S. aureus species [12]. Resistance to vancomycin by altered structure of the cell wall pentapeptide is one example of target bypassing. Expression of class A tetracycline efflux pump encoded by TetA and TetA-1 genes is a major resistance mechanism against tetracycline among the Gram-negative bacteria such as E. coli [13].

sections.heading: 3.1.1. S. aureus
sections.text:
S. aureus is a part of the normal flora of skin, respiratory tract, and nasopharynx of humans, which act as an opportunistic pathogen. Prominent infectious diseases related to this bacterium are intestinal, respiratory, blood, and skin infections. Toxins of S. aureus can lead to scalded-skin syndrome, food poisoning, and toxic-shock syndrome. The wound infections caused by S. aureus are groups of the common nosocomial infections which have been more complicated by emergence of MRSA strains. Genetically, there are two main types of MRSA strain based on the presence of mecA and mecC resistance genes in their genome. These genes encode PBP-2a with a low affinity for β-lactam antibiotics such as penicillin and cephalosporin [14]. Also, antibiotic resistance S. aureus can produce
Article highlights
● Annually, 100,000 tons of antibiotics are produced to treat bacterial infections. However, these antibiotics have failed to control MDR bacteria, and therefore, there is a pressing need to search for novel antibiotics or other alternatives. ● Several mechanisms can contribute to antibiotic resistance of bacteria involving a reduction in the drug uptake, modifications of the antibacterial target, activation of efflux mechanisms for extrusion of the antibacterial agents, and global alterations in prominent metabolic pathways. ● MNPs and MNCs with unique properties compared to bulk materials and conventional antibiotics can be considered as new suitable weapon against MDR bacteria. ● There are several methods for synthesis of these nanomaterials. Among these, biogenic synthesis is eco-friendly and economically viable. ● Recent studies have provided evidence that antibacterial activities of MNPs and MNCs may be resulted from several mechanisms including blistering (blebs), clumping of membranes, and blockage of electron transport chain.
β-lactamase enzyme having hydrolysis ability of β-lactam ring. This enzyme is under expression of the blaZ gene activation [15]. In another aspect, MRSA is classified as nosocomial, nonnosocomial, and livestock-associated MRSA [16]. These bacterial strains can cause pneumonia, bacteremia, and infections in soft tissues, skin, and bone.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. S. pneumoniae
sections.text:
S. pneumoniae as a Gram-positive bacterium causes various respiratory infections such as community-associated pneumonia, chronic and acute bronchitis, acute bacterial sinusitis, and other dangerous infections including bacteremia and meningitis. In the case of penicillin-resistant S. pneumoniae, 80% and 60% values were reported for Asian and Latin American countries,
respectively. Although, S. pneumoniae does not synthesize β-lactamase, it has resistance ability to β-lactam antibiotics by mutations in subunits of PBPs. These proteins are targets for β-lactam antibiotics. This type of resistance in S. pneumoniae can be resulted from horizontal gene transfer between pathogen and streptococci [17]. Other antibiotic resistance in S. pneumoniae is modification of targets (DNA topoisomerase and gyrase enzymes) for quinolones antibiotics such as fluoroquinolones. In this way, antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin (Cipro), moxifloxacin (Avelox), and gemifloxacin (Factive) have not antibacterial impact in their standard minimum inhibition concentration (MIC). In addition, resistant S. pneumoniae can use efflux pumps and target modification for escape from macrolide antibiotics involving josamycin and erythromycin [1].

sections.heading: 3.1.3. S. epidermidis
sections.text: Biofilm-associated infections are mainly the results of S. epidermidis virulence in patients with surgical implants and catheters. These infections are complicated in immunocompromised patients [18]. Antibiotic resistance of S. epidermidis is resulted from inhibitory activity of biofilm to antibiotics. Biofilm structure of these bacteria has polysaccharide intercellular adhesin which facilitates adhesion to hospital-associated devices. Moreover, methicillin resistance up to 90% rate by mecA gene is responsible for 70% of nosocomial infections related to S. epidermidis. Macrolides such as erythromycin can be effluxed by S. epidermidis having srA gene [1].

sections.heading: 3.2.1. E. coli
sections.text: Some serotypes of E. coli can be pathogen by production of Shiga toxin. Urinary tract infections, gastroenteritis, hemorrhagic colitis, Crohn’s disease, and neonatal meningitis are associated with virulent strains of E. coli such as O157:H7 and O104:H4. Antibiotics involving rifaximin, fluoroquinolones, and azithromycin are effective agents against nonresistant strains of E. coli. Extended spectrum β-lactamases (ESBLs) can be synthesized by MDR E. coli containing plasmids of antibiotic resistance (CTX-M). These strains have developed resistance against monobactams, cephalosporins, quinolones, and aminoglycosides [19]. In addition, modification of porins (OmpF, OmpC, and PhoE) in outer membrane of E. coli is another resistancemechanism. In this case, there is a lack of porin function, and expression also changes in the type of porins. AcrAB-TolC system is another approach of resistance in which E. coli uses efflux pump to expel fluoroquinolones, chloramphenicol, fusidic acid, tetracyclines, β-lactams, and novobiocin [1].

sections.heading: 3.2.2. P. aeruginosa
sections.text:
Major infections of P. aeruginosa can be categorized in five groups: (1) skin and soft tissues, (2) lungs (pneumonia), (3) gastrointestinal, (4) urinary tract, and (5) septic shock (blood) infections. In patients with cystic fibrosis disease, resulted pneumonia from P. aeruginosa colonization in lung epithelial cells as well as production of pyocyanin virulence factor may be difficult to treat. Nosocomial infections caused by P. aeruginosa are most frequent in hospital devices such as catheter, implants, and other prosthesis. These infections are caused by biofilm

formation and resistance to wide range of antibiotics. Moreover, wound and burn infections caused by this bacterium is yet main problem in health-care-associated parts [20]. P. aeruginosa is resistant to antibiotic by using various mechanisms. Enzyme of Verona Integron-encoded Metallo β-lactamase (VIM) is responsible for destruction of β-lactams antibiotics such as carbapenemase. Resistance to cephalosporins and β-lactams is resulted from expression of chromosomal or plasmid (infrequent)-mediated AmpC genes [1]. In addition, OXA-11 strain of P. aeruginosa can destruct third-generation cephalosporins. Alterations of target-binding site as well as reduction of internal antibiotic concentrations by lack of porins and application of efflux pumps are other important mechanisms of antibiotic resistance in this bacterium [21].

sections.heading: 3.2.3. A. baumannii
sections.text: A. baumannii has been classified in ESKAPE group of pathogens including Enterobacter Spp., Enterococcus faecium, P. aeruginosa, S. aureus, Acinetobacter baumannii, and Klebsiella pneumoniae) which have high degree of antibiotic resistance in nosocomial infections. A. baumannii can cause ventilator-associated pneumonia, bloodstream,meningitis, wounds, surgical injuries, and urinary tract infections [22]. In A. baumannii, there are variousmechanisms pertaining to antibiotic resistance such as Ambler class D penicillinase, metallo-β-lactamase (IMP and VIM), Ambler class D β-lactamase OXA-143, carbapenemases OXA-58-like and OXA-23 [23]. A. baumannii can use OXA-23 and OXA-48 enzymes of class D βlactamase to destruct carbapenems antibiotics. This opportunistic pathogen as a Gram-negative bacterium with hydrophobicity of outer membrane can naturally decrease penetration of hydrophilic antibiotics such as tetracyclines, some fluoroquinolones, and penicillinase [1]. Also, AdeB and AdeDE are two important types of efflux pumps which MDR A. baumannii uses to extrude aminoglycoside and β-lactam antibiotics, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. K. pneumoniae
sections.text: Recently, nosocomial infections caused by K. pneumoniae have attracted much attention than other Enterobacter species. Infections of lungs (pneumonia), intestinal tract, urinary tract, thrombophlebitis, cholecystitis, osteomyelitis, meningitis, septicemia, and wounds are resulted from pathogenicity of K. pneumoniae. It is worth mentioning that 50% rate of mortality was reported for bloodstream infection due to this pathogen [24]. Cephalosporin resistance in K. pneumoniae can be transferred horizontally by CTX-M (a plasmid-encoded ESBL). Binding site protection of DNA topoisomerase IV and gyrase against quinolone antibiotic is another mechanism of resistance in this bacterium. Change in porin proteins from OmpK35 to OmpK36 has been observed in K. pneumoniae with extended resistance to βlactam antibiotics. In addition, destruction ability of β-lactams by expression of plasmid-mediated blaNDM gene is another way of antibiotic resistance [1].

sections.heading: 3.2.5. S. marcescens
sections.text:
S. marcescens, as opportunistic pathogen, is responsible for hospital-acquired infections such as meningitis, pneumonia, urinary tract, ocular (conjunctivitis, keratitis, and endophthalmitis), and wounds infections. This bacterium utilizes ShlA (a main virulence factor and a hemolysin) and
PhlA (phospholipase) exoenzymes to perform its pathogenicity. Resistance to carbapenems is common in S. marcescens which can be caused by class A carbapenemase enzymes located on its chromosome. Non-sensitivity to imipenem, meropenem, and ertapenem antibiotics with MIC values of >128, ≥16, and ≥8 mg/L was reported from South-East England. In this context, blaSME genes were recognized for these functions [25].

sections.heading: 4.1. Silver
sections.text: Use of silver as antimicrobial agent dates back over 7000 years. Instability of silver salts and release of Ag+ ions is important antimicrobial function of these salts. These ions can form holes and pits in cell membrane; as a result leakage of macromolecules involving proteins and nucleic acids takes place. These mechanisms are prominent in NPs of silver [26–29]. Interaction of Ag+ ions with amino acid of cysteine with thiol (-SH) group in proteins specifically respiratory enzymes result in inefficiency of respiratory system of bacteria. Free radicals of oxygen as hydroxyl radical (OH*), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and superoxide (O2*) are results of this interaction [30]. Many researchers have reported AgNPs as powerful antibacterial agents. For instance, the inhibition zone diameter (IZD) values for 50 μg/mL concentration of ceftriaxone-conjugated AgNPs and unconjugated AgNPs were 23 and 18 mm, respectively [31]. A. baumannii showed sensitivity as IZD, MIC and minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) amounts of 21.2 ± 0.4 mm, 1.95, and 15.62 μg/ mL, respectively. Moreover, biofilm formation of this bacterium reduced meaningfully under AgNPs stress than control [32]. Phytosynthesis of AgNPs by Chaenomeles sinensis fruit extract with size of 20–40 nm exhibited 11 ± 0.00 and 14.66 ± 0.33mmof IZD for S. aureus and E. coli, respectively at 45 μg/disk concentration [33]. In another study, IZD value of 19 mm was recorded for S. aureus after treatment of biosynthesized AgNPs (20 μL amount) [34]. Phytosynthesized AgNPs by Citrus × clementine with mean diameter size of 15–20 nm demonstrated MBC values of 50 ± 2.2 and 60 ± 2.8 μg/mL against E. coli and S. aureus, respectively [35]. Spherical AgNPs synthesized by Prosopis juliflora bark extract with average particle size of 10–50 nm had more antibacterial effect on E. coli than P. aeruginosa at 1 μg concentration [36]. In addition to plant and bacterial source, Gelidium amansii as marine red alga was utilized to synthesize AgNPs with 27–54 nm size. These NPs showed antibiofilm activities against P. aeruginosa and S. aureus as 99% reduction than control samples at 100 μg concentration [37]. Antibacterial activity of phytosynthesized AgNPs via stembark of Ficus krishnaewas reported as values of 18 and 12mm in the case of E. coliMTCC 45 and S. aureus ATCC 29122, respectively [38]. In comparative study, MBC amounts for P. aeruginosa ATCC14886, E. coli ATCC 25922, and S. aureus ATCC 9144 under stress of curcumin-AgNPs were 20, and 10, and 10 mg/L respectively than AgNPs with 20, 30, and 20 mg/L values [39]. In their previous study, anti-planktonic and antibiofilm functions of green synthesized Ag-TiO2, TiO2-Ag, Ag-Cu, and Cu-Ag NCs were compared. The results of this work showed highest antibacterial activity of Ag-TiO2 on MDR bacteria including E. coli ATCC 25922, P. aeruginosa ATCC 27853, and S. aureus ATCC 43300 [40].

sections.heading: 4.2. Copper and copper oxides
sections.text: Application of copper (Cu) and copper oxides (CuO and Cu2O) NPs as potential antibacterial agents was reported in recent years [41,42]. In this regard, green synthesis of Cu NPs has been successful by several biomaterials such as thymol and usnic acid [43]. For instance, biosynthesis of Cu NPs by Pleurotus ostreatus fungus and natural polysaccharides produced 36 and 31 nm size respectively. Antibacterial activity of these NPs was 16 and 15 mm values of IZD for K. pneumoniae and S. aureus, respectively [44]. In eco-friendly method, leaf extract of Bauhinia tomentosa was used for synthesis of CuO NPs and evaluated against P. aeruginosa and E. coli with IZD of 17 and 22mm, respectively [45]. In another study, core-shell structure of CuO at AgNPs had higher antibacterial efficacy on pathogenic strain of S. aureus ATCC 29213 at 2 μg/mL concentration [46]. Biosynthesis of Cu NPs (20–160 nm) by reducing function of monosaccharide and polysaccharides showed antibacterial activity against E. coli DH5α strain as IZD of 12 mm [47]. Moreover, S. epidermidis and S. aureus exhibited high sensitivity upon antibacterial and antibiofilm stresses of Fe-doped CuO NPs [48]. Comparatively, complex of sulfide and Cu as copper sulfide NPs had less antibacterial activity than ZnO/Zn(OH)2-NPs. In this case, MBC results of CuS NPs were 9.77, 4.88, 19.53, and 1.22 μg/mL for K. pneumoniae, A. baumannii, E. coli, and S. aureus respectively than ZnO/Zn(OH)2-NPs by 39.06, 19.53, 78.13, and 4.88 μg/mL [49]. Coating TiO2 plates by 3 g/L concentration of Cu NPs showed a significant antibacterial impact on S. aureus than 0.3 g/L Cu NPs and control samples [50].

sections.heading: 4.3. Iron oxides
sections.text: In nature, there are three main forms of iron oxides named as alpha-Fe2O3 (hematite), gamma-Fe2O3 (maghemite), and Fe3O4 (magnetite). Various physical, chemical, and green methods are used for the preparation of Iron oxide NPs [51]. Application of iron oxide NPs in composites form with antibacterial agents showed activities because of their magnetic, biocompatibility, and biodegradability properties. For instance, Fe3O4 NPs improved antibacterial and physicochemical properties of chitosan/gelatin composite. In this way, IZDs of chitosan/gelatin and Fe3O4/chitosan/gelatin composites (with 4 wt% amount of Fe3O4) for S. aureus were found to be 13 ± 2 and 20 ± 2 mm, respectively. The release of Fe2+ ions is one of the important reasons for antibacterial activity and cytotoxicity of gamma-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 NPs [52]. In addition, E. coli showed more sensitivity by values of 15 ± 1 and 21 ± 1 mm, respectively [53]. In another study, antibacterial effects of Fe3O4@Ag@Ni nanocomposites (with cubic shape and average particle size of 15 nm) on Gram-negative and Gram-positive pathogens were higher than imipenem antibiotic [54]. Magnetic property of Fe3O4 NPs was used for targeting MDR bacteria such as E. coli and S. aureus. In this study, Fe3O4 NPs/polydopamine/poly(amidoamine)/N-diazeniumdiolate composite has photodynamic and controllable nitric oxide (NO) abilities against MDR bacteria [55]. In another report, 18–21% values of growth reduction by E. coli MTCC405 and S. aureus MTCC 3160 were observed upon stress of Hibiscus sabdariffa flowers extract capped iron NPs [56].

sections.heading: 4.4. Titanium dioxide
sections.text: Prominent properties of TiO2 are hydrophobicity, photocatalytic, and biocompatibility which are important in industry and medicine fields. Three common crystalline forms for TiO2 are rutile, anatase, and brookite. Among these crystalline forms, more antibacterial properties were reported for anatase. UV lights (UV-A, B, and C) can release electron and electron holes from TiO2 NPs which can be used in photocatalyst and antibacterial applications. In this case, Ag-doped TiO2 NPs have higher antibacterial effects on E. coli, P. aeruginosa, Bacillus subtilis, and S. aureus pathogens than pure forms of Ag and TiO2 NPs [57]. Also, 20 min of UV-A radiation of nano-TiO2 (anatase)-based thin films resulted in no colony forming unit (CFU) for the case of E. coli MC1061 [58]. In similar study, pulsed laser ablation synthesized TiO2 NPs demonstrated significant antibacterial activities against E. coli in 60min of UV radiation [59]. Application of graphene oxide and reduced graphene oxide for preparation of nanocomposites by TiO2 was effective with regard to antimicrobial and photocatalytic abilities. In this instance, high degree of *OH production with antibacterial activity against E. coli ATCC 25922 was observed for magnetic graphene oxides-TiO2 nanocomposites with 200 mg/L concentration [52]. Nanocomposites of Cu2O-TiO2 NPs/reduced graphene oxide with mean size of 17 nm had IZDs of 27, 25, 25, and 24 mm for S. aureus, Streptococcus oralis, E. coli, and P. aeruginosa pathogens, respectively [60]. Antibacterial activities of TiO2 can be enhanced by using semiconductors with lower band gap energy. In this context, reduction of band gap energy of TiO2 (3.2 eV) to 2.38 eV by using AgI in preparation of AgI/TiO2 nanocomposites had significant photocatalytic activity against E. coli under visible light radiation [61]. In addition, Ag NPs loaded TiO2 nanotube showed 99.27% antibacterial activity against S. aureus at 100 μg/ mL after 1 h under dark condition [62].

sections.heading: 4.5. Zinc oxide
sections.text:
First step in antibacterial function of ZnO NPs is electrostatic attachment of NPs to bacterial envelope [26,63]. Antibacterial activity of ZnO NPs was approximately similar to TiO2 with wide band gap of 3.37 eV and production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) [30]. ROS and pit formation on cell membrane surface were caused mainly by release of Zn2+ ions from ZnO NPs. Reduction in biofilm formation of E. coli as values of 95% and 80% respectively in dark and visible light conditions were observed for green synthesized ZnO NPs by Ulva lactuca seaweed extract (average diameter size of 10–50 nm) [64]. In a similar study, spherical ZnO NPs with mean diameter of 20– 50 nm were prepared by aqueous extract of Tabernaemontana divaricata. These NPs had significant higher activities against E. coli and S. aureus than plant extract [65]. In another study, disk diffusion results of hydrothermal synthesized ZnO/Ag HSs nanocomposites (with mean particle size of 10–20 nm) showed more antibacterial activity on S. aureus than E. coli [66]. For improvement of biocompatibility and biodegradability of ZnO NPs, several approaches have been applied based on organic and inorganic modifications. For instance, exopolysaccharide (EPS) of Bacillus licheniformis Dahb1 was used to modify ZnO NPs via co-precipitation method. In the case of antibacterial
activity, IZDs from 11.5 ± 0.97 to 10.13 ± 0.40 mm were observed for P. aeruginosa Dahp1 (HQ4006631) at 100 μg/mL of EPS-ZnO NPs [67]. Comparison of ZnO with 5 wt% Ag/ZnO micro/nanoflowers against E. coli at 180 min of visible light irradiation showed significant bactericidal potential of nanocomposites than pure ZnO [68]. In addition, ZnO NPs (size 20– 30 nm) were synthesized by using tween 80, oleic acid, and gluconic acid as surfactant/capping/reducing agents. These MNPs demonstrated antibacterial activity against E. coli and S. aureus by mechanisms of cell necrosis and peptidoglycan wall damage [69].

sections.heading: 4.6. Magnesium oxide
sections.text: Safety of magnesium oxide (MgO) in food packaging and pharmacy was approved by food and drug administration. Under light condition,MgONPs can produce ROS and cause oxidative stress in lipids ofmembrane (lipid peroxidation), proteins, and nucleic acids of bacteria [26]. Green synthesized hexagonal MgO NPs with average particle size of 50 nm by leave extract of Costus pictus had antibacterial effects on S. aureus and E. coli as IZD of 5 and 13 mm, respectively [70]. MgO NPs with flake shape and average diameter size of 10–11 nmwere synthesized by Bauhinia purpurea leaf extract via alkaline precipitation [71]. These NPs showed MIC value of 250 μg/mL for S. aureus MTCC-3384 by mechanisms of ROS production and membrane disruption. In comparative study, Mg2+ ions were reduced by aqueous extract of two plant species including Psidium guajava and Aloe vera. Resulted MgO NPs had mean particle size of 50–90 nm with different antibacterial activities. In addition, IZD of biosynthesizedMgONPs by P. guajava and A. vera extract were 15 and 12 mm, respectively when tested against E. coli [72]. Other shape (nanorod) of MgO NPs with diameter of 46 nm was biosynthesized by leave extract of Eucalyptus globulus. For this case, mechanism of biosynthesis was explained by enol-to-keto transformation of phenols and flavonoids. In this study, effects of precursor concentration, extract volume, and reaction time on nanorod size of MgO NPs were surveyed in controlled condition [73]. Doping of silver into MgO NPs via sol-gel method resulted in amorphous shape of Ag-doped MgO NCs by average particle size of 30 nm. These MNCs or MgO NCs (1%) reduced E. coli population as 7-log after 20 min by production of ROS specifically superoxide radical [74].

sections.heading: 4.7. Ruthenium NPs
sections.text:
Ruthenium (Ru) is rare transition metal of the platinum group with the oxidation states in the range from 0 to +8, and −2. Recently, NP of this metal has attracted more attention in medical field particularly in rapid diagnosis and treatment of microbial infections. Bactericidal activities of green synthesized Ru NPs (in the range of 20–90 nm) by Gloriosa superba leaf extract demonstrated against B. subtilis, S. aureus, S. pneumoniae, E. coli, P. aeruginosa, and K. pneumoniae [75]. In a similar study, ruthenium oxide (RuO2) NPs by size range of 6–25 nm were fabricated by leaf extract of Acalypha indica. These NPs showed MBC values of 8, 10, 12, and 12 μg/ml for E. coli, P. aeruginosa, S. marcescens, and S. aureus, respectively [76]. Surface modification of Ru NPs by acetylcholine showed photothermal and photodynamic (irradiated by 808 nm laser) effects on MDR strains of P.
aeruginosa and S. aureus [77]. Ability of infection diagnosis by these NPs is related to suitable florescence resulted from their high luminous properties. For this case, 1-ethyl-3-[3-dimethylaminopropyl] carbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC) and N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) were used to activate and conjugate Se NPs to Ru NPs having UBI 29-41 peptide (PEP)as Se@PEP-Ru NCs. In this study, uptake of Se@PEP-Ru NCs by S. aureus and E. coli was detected as fluorescent emission under laser confocal fluorescence microscopy. Also, targeting and disruption of the bacterial cell membranes were observed for these NCs [78].

sections.heading: 5. Mechanisms of MNPs/metal oxide NPs interaction with bacteria
sections.text:
In first step, identification of morphological features in MNPs and bacteria is required to understand interaction of MNPs or metal oxide NPswith bacteria. Based on cell wall morphology, there are two major types of bacteria involving Gram-positive and Gramnegative, which are used for evaluation of antibiotics. In Grampositive bacteria, cell wall of bacteria is composed of thick peptidoglycan layer and cell membrane. In contrast, in Gram-negative bacteria, plasmamembrane, outer membrane, and thin peptidoglycan are components of cell wall. In these bacteria, there is periplasmic space between plasma and outer membranes. Bacterial cell walls of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria are 20–80 and 10–30 nm thick, respectively. This difference is related to 95% and 5–10% amount of peptidoglycan for Grampositive and Gram-negative bacteria, respectively [79].
These properties can determine bacterial response to antibacterial agents such as MNPs. It is worth mentioning that particles with 2 nm can penetrate easily in peptidoglycan layer. Other important property is charge of bacterial envelope which is associated to total charge of cell wall components. Generally, Grampositive and Gram-negative bacteria have negative charge resulted from anionic properties of teichoic acids and lipopolysaccharides in their cell surface [80]. In this regard, oxidation of MNPs/ metal oxideNPswith release of positive ions such asAg+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ can adsorb on the bacterial surface and lead to cell wall damage by formation of pit in most Gram-negative bacteria [26]. Also, this electrostatic interaction between positive charge of metal ions and negative charge of cell envelop causes change in efflux and influx of biomaterials from bacteria. In Figure 3, other results of this interaction have been shown, which are blistering (blebs), clumping of membranes, and blockage of electron transport chain [41]. In surface or inner part of bacteria, MNPs (mean diameter size of 10–12 nm) can bind to sulfur-containing amino acids specifically cysteine, homocysteine, and methionine [9]. Cysteine aminoacidswith thiol functional grouphavemoreaffinity to attach metal ions. In inner part of bacteria, this attachment may lead to change of enzyme function such as NADH (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) dehydrogenases [81]. Both planktonic and biofilm forms of bacteria can be disrupted by ions released from MNPs. Other antibacterial aspect of MNPs is ROS formation resulted from higher activity of MNPs. Active ions such as Cu2+, Zn2+, and Mg2+ can react with H2O2 and produce ROS. In the case of metal oxide NPs such as ZnO and MgO, photocatalytic properties have important effect on antibacterial activities. Photocatalysis of these semiconductor NPs is due to electron-hole formation by excitation of electron from valence band to conduction band
under light or UV radiation. Reaction between electron holes with H2O molecules produces ROS [82]. Surface properties of MNPs involving high surface to volume ratio and low degree of crystallinity are effective factors in augmenting antibacterial activity.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: To sum up, MDR mechanisms and important virulence properties of MDR bacteria including S. aureus, S. pneumoniae, and S. epidermidis (Gram positive) as well as E. coli, P. aeruginosa, A. baumannii, S. marcescens, and K. pneumoniae (Gram-negative) have been discussed in the present review. Moreover, all aspects of antibacterial activities demonstrated by novel MNPs andMNCs such as Ru NPs and Se-Ru NCs have been described in light of the recent studies. In addition, MNPs andMNCs synthesis methods with their antibacterial mechanisms against these bacteria have been described according to recent advancements. It is worth noting thatmechanismof antiplanktonic and antibiofilmactivity ofMNPs/ metal oxide NPs or MNCs are not still well understood and therefore, there is need of further extensive studies to address the problem.

sections.heading: 7. Expert opinion
sections.text:
Application of noble metals specifically silver and copper as antimicrobial agents has been approved by ancient civilizations such as Egyptians, Indians, and Persians. Extraction and discovery of penicillin from Penicillium notatum in 1928 by a Scottish scientist, Alexander Fleming, changed microbial infections therapy. However, antibiotic resistance as an emerging crisis in microorganisms particularly in pathogenic bacteria is increasing because natural selection phenomenon resulted from antibiotic misuse by human. Particularly, antibiotic resistance in bacteria has different appearances involving MDR, extensively drug resistance, and pan-drug resistance. Non-susceptibility to at least one antibiotic in three or more antimicrobial groups defined as MDR. E. coli, S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, A. baumannii, K. pneumoniae, S. marcescens, S. pneumoniae, and S. epidermidis are important pathogenic bacteria which have shown MDR against a wide range of conventional antibiotics. In this regard, antibacterial efficacy of MNPs and MNCs on these pathogens has demonstrated considerable efficacy. High surface to volume ratio of MNPs is unique property than to bulk materials. Several mechanisms concerning activities of MNPs/metal oxide NPs and MNCs against pathogenic bacteria which are mainly dependent on type of their precursors and treated bacterium have been investigated. In addition, there are many studies about antibacterial properties of these nanomaterials with similar and different results. These mechanisms can be interaction of MNPs with amino acids having sulfhydryl group such as cysteine, increased permeability of cell membrane, cell wall clumping, membrane blistering, cell respiration blockage, pit formation, nucleic acids damage, and cell wall disruption. Impacts of MNPs on bacteria can be performed in outer (extra-cytoplasmic) and inner (intra-cytoplasmic) parts of cell wall or membrane. Peptidoglycan and cell membrane are respectively first barriers in Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria versus these nanomaterials. For the case of extra-cytoplasmic interaction, attachment of MNPs/metal oxide NPs with biological macromolecules of cell wall and cell membrane via thiol group is common process. Each of these effects may be influenced by several factors related to experiment such as size or shape uniformity and precise concentration of MNPs. In this way, amorphous MNPs/metal oxide NPs have shown higher antibacterial activities compared to crystalline ones. Furthermore, there have been more antibacterial results associated to MNPs having diameter size less than 50 nm. Antibacterial assays should not be ignored. For reliable results, researchers need various
tests about different aspects of antibacterial functions of MNPs. These assays can be divided into two major groups including antiplanktonic and antibiofilm methods. For antiplanktonic groups, disk diffusion assay, MIC, MBC, determination of CFU, and kinetic growth of bacteria upon treatment of different concentrations of MNPs may be useful. Also, antibiofilm activities of MNPs can be carried out by crystal violet or fluorescence staining followed by observation under optical microscope. Atomic force microscope, scanning electron microscope, and transmission electron microscope are other important tools for detail observation of MNPs antibacterial effects. Surface modification is other major issue for improvement of MNPs. Moreover, several antibiotics such as tetracycline, penicillin, and amoxicillin have already demonstrated synergistic antibacterial effect when used in combination with MNPs and MNCs. It is worth noting that surface properties of MNPs can be affected by preparation methods. From nano-toxicology aspect, cytotoxicity of MNPs should be evaluated. This may be performed by in vitro and in vivo techniques. Therefore, enhanced antioxidant activity of MNPs is indispensable for significant results. In addition, encapsulation of MNPs by organic and inorganic materials is another approach. Finally, there is one important question: can bacteria apply novel mechanisms to escape or neutralize MNPs? Considering the ability of bacteria to develop resistance to antibiotics, this is possible. Therefore, suitable improvement of these nanomaterials is essential, which warrants further investigation. It should be noted that fighting against elite pathogenic microorganisms is not still a story with end.
Antibacterial applications of MNPs and MNCs are accompanied by high toxicity effects on both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells. Low biocompatibility and biodegradability in physiological medium is disadvantage of MNPs and MNCs, and hence the future studies should be focused on solving this issue. In this context, surface modification of MNPs and MNCs by inorganic and organic materials may prove to be useful. For example, catechol-functionalized polypeptide (polysarcosine and dopamine-modified polyglutamic acid) was used to modification of AgNPs followed by coating on TiO2 substrate. In this study, catechol had two functions including anchoring group to TiO2 surface and reducing of Ag ions for AgNPs formation. Antibacterial efficacy of this nanomaterial against E. coli was found to be approximately 100% [83]. In addition, encapsulation formulation of these nanomaterials in macro/nanocarriers such as polymeric NPs is another option. Natural polymers such as chitosan, cellulose, and collagen are common biomaterials with high biocompatibility and biodegradability. Among these biopolymers, chitosan with intrinsic antimicrobial properties is suitable choice to encapsulate MNPs. For this purpose, in comparative study, chitosan-Cu, chitosan-CuO, chitosan-Cu-chitosan, and chitosan-CuO-chitosan NC films illustrated IZDs values of 14, 16, 6, and 10 mm, respectively.

metadata.abstractText: Introduction: In recent years, multidrug resistance (MDR) in bacteria has drastically increased and has posed a great threat to the human health. This problem has generated an urgent need to search alternatives for the treatment of MDR bacteria. It has been proved that metal nanoparticles (MNPs) and metal nanocomposites (MNCs) possess remarkable antimicrobial potential, and hence can be used in alternative therapy. Areas covered: This review is aimed to discuss recent reports on antibacterial activities of MNPs and MNCs against MDR bacteria. Expert opinion: Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Acinetobacter baumannii, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Serratia marcescens, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Staphylococcus epidermidis are important pathogenic bacteria which have shown MDR against a wide range of conventional antibiotics. In this context, effects of MNPs and MNCs on these pathogens have demonstrated considerable efficacy. Several mechanisms concerning activity of MNPs and MNCs against pathogenic bacteria which are mainly dependent on type of their precursors and treated bacterium have been investigated. In addition, many studies have been made on antibacterial activities of these nanomaterials with similar and different results. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 3 March 2019 Accepted 1 May 2019
